what is the COM-B Model? Elaborate step by step as to how Cowry has been using it.

The COM-B Model is a behavior change framework that is made up of three components: Capability (C), Opportunity (O), and Motivation (M). These components interact to influence behavior (B) and behavior in turn influences the components, creating a feedback loop. The model is useful in identifying factors that help determine what behavior needs to be changed in an environment.

Cowry Consulting has been using the COM-B Model to help their clients create new services, products, campaigns, or environments. They use the model to identify the factors that contribute to behavior change and to provide a comprehensive framework for understanding behavior change. Cowry also uses the model to supplement the Behavior Change Wheel, which helps combat the critique that the model is too simplistic. Cowry also uses the model to help their clients identify the components that need to be changed in order to maximize the new behavior and reduce the risk of old behaviors being repeated.

What is the HOOK model?

The Hook Model is a behavior change framework developed by Eyal (2014) that explains how products and services engage customers through four components: Messenger, Incentives, Norms, Defaults, Salience, Priming, Affect, Commitment, and Ego. The model suggests that attention is drawn to stimuli that are novel, accessible, and simple, and that cues or primes can influence behavior by creating emotional associations. It is useful in identifying factors that help determine what behavior needs to be changed in an environment.

What do you know about TAM?

The Technology Acceptance Model (TAM) is an information systems theory that models how users accept and use technology. It suggests that when users encounter a new technology, various factors influence their decision on whether and how they will use it. The model consists of two elements: perceived usefulness and perceived ease of use. Perceived usefulness is the extent to which a person believes that using a particular technology will enhance their experience, while perceived ease of use is the extent to which a person believes that using a particular technology will require little effort. When a technology is perceived as useful and easy to use, it positively impacts attitudes toward the technology, which increases behavioral intentions and drives system usage.

What are the C-Factors?

The C-Factors are cognitive biases that influence decision-making. They include Optimism Bias, Superiority Bias, Present Bias, Priming, Ambiguity Aversion (process and time), Anchoring, and Comparative Ignorance Hypothesis.
Can you talk about Ambiguity Aversion?

Yes, Ambiguity Aversion is a phenomenon where people prefer to partake in activities where the probabilities are known, such as gambling, over activities where the decisions rely on uncertainties, such as choosing an appropriate life insurance policy. People may avoid engaging with processes that are unclear or overly complex. This phenomenon has been studied in a variety of contexts, such as when people were asked to pick a black ball from an urn where the probabilities of the other one were unknown, or when people were asked to wait for a doctor's appointment with either a specific, realistic waiting time or were told they only had to wait 10 minutes and were then periodically updated that it would be 10 minutes longer. Additionally, people's perceptions and judgements can be influenced by a variety of informational signals, such as when people were asked to bid on items in an auction and were first asked to write down the last 2 digits of their social security number, or when a firefighting unit in the US informed householders that they ideally need 5 smoke alarms in their house. Finally, people often mentally create a special “money jar” that is set aside for a holiday, while still carrying substantial credit card debt, and this special fund is treated differently from the money used to pay off debt, even though it’s objectively exactly the same.
What is the psychology behind Ambiguity Aversion?

The psychology behind Ambiguity Aversion is that people have a preference for risks that are associated with known probabilities. People are more likely to complete a process or task if their expectations are managed appropriately, and they tend to avoid decisions where the choices and commitments are ambiguous. This is because when faced with uncertainty, people may become overwhelmed and avoid engaging with the process. Additionally, people's perceptions and judgements can be influenced by a variety of informational signals, such as the first piece of information they are presented with, even if it is irrelevant to the decision. This process is known as anchoring, and can lead to people making decisions based on the initial information they are presented with.

Tell me about Tagore?

Rabindranath Tagore was a Bengali polymath who reshaped his region's literature and music. He was the first non-European to win the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1913. He was a humanist, universalist internationalist, and strident anti-nationalist who denounced the Raj and advocated independence from Britain. He was highly influential in introducing the best of Indian culture to the West and vice versa. 

Tagore was born in the Jorasanko mansion in Calcutta, India to parents Debendranath Tagore (1817–1905) and Sarada Devi (1830–1875). He wrote poetry as an eight-year-old and released his first substantial poems under the pseudonym Bhanusi?ha ("Sun Lion") at age sixteen. He graduated to his first short stories and dramas—and the aegis of his birth name—by 1877. 

Tagore modernised Bengali art by spurning rigid classical forms and resisting linguistic strictures. His works include Gitanjali (Song Offerings), Gora (Fair-Faced), and Ghare-Baire (The Home and the World). He is also known for his novels, stories, songs, dance-dramas, and essays. His compositions were chosen by two nations as national anthems: the Republic of India's Jana Gana Mana and Bangladesh's Amar Shonar Bangla. 

Tagore interacted with Henri Bergson, Albert Einstein, Robert Frost, Thomas Mann, George Bernard Shaw, H.G. Wells and Romain Rolland. He wrote his Oxford Hibbert Lectures and spoke at the annual London Quaker meet. He visited Agha Khan III, stayed at Dartington Hall, toured Denmark, Switzerland, and Germany, and went on into the Soviet Union. He also visited Persia and Iraq (in 1932) and Sri Lanka (in 1933).

Tell me about some of your works

My most famous poem, Sonar Tori, deals with the fleeting endurance of life and achievement. I also wrote Gitanjali, which is my best-known collection internationally and earned me the Nobel Prize. I wrote these works in reaction to the halfhearted uptake of modernist and realist techniques in Bengali literature. I wanted to explore the element of unpredictability in art and create something that could speak without the need of an interpreter. I also spoke out against the Revivalist movement in art, which sought to link art with nationalism and glorify the past. Did you go to University College, London?

I was against bookish learning and wanted students to gather knowledge and materials from different regions of the country, from direct sources and from their own independent efforts. I founded Visva Bharati, my conception of a world university, with a determination to go beyond aggressive nationalism and to build friendship with all nations.
